metadata.title: Vanadium poisoning of FCC catalysts: A quantitative analysis of impregnated and real equilibrium catalysts

Fig. 1 Typical EPR spectrum of a real contaminated catalyst sample collected from a FCC unit with partial burn regeneration (ECAT-5). Calculated EPR spectra due to Fe3+ from kaolin, VO2+ and an unproven species (broad EPR line) are shown below as colored solid lines. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 EPR spectra of (a) V impregnated and (b) real FCC catalyst samples; experimental spectra (after background subtraction) and calculated derivative spectra (colored lines). Fig. 2 Fig. 3 (a) EPR spectra of anhydrous vanadyl sulfate as a function of mass (1–10 mg); (b) EPR spectra of the C-4 catalyst sample impregnated with vanadyl sulfate (1500 ppm V) with sample mass varying between10 mg and 150 mg. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 (a) Area of the EPR spectra as a function of the mass of pure vanadyl sulfate (0–10 mg); (b) Area of the EPR spectra of impregnated vanadyl ions on the C-4 catalyst as a function of mass (0 to 150 mg). Fig. 4 Fig. 5 EPR spectra of V impregnated catalysts from 200 ppm to 1500 ppm (a, b) impregnated with EDTA before and after deactivation; (c, d) impregnated without EDTA before and after deactivation. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 EPR spectra of a vanadium impregnated sample (1500 ppm) thermally treated at different temperatures for 1 h and atmospheres: (a) oxidizing (air) and (b) reducing (H2:N2, 10:90) atmospheres. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 EPR spectra of virgin catalyst (not impregnated) thermally treated under reducing atmosphere (a) at different temperatures for 5 min. (b) at 500 °C for different times. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 EPR spectra measured at room temperature of real catalyst samples(a) ECAT-3 (b) ECAT-5, before (black line) and after (red line) further regeneration step in pilot unit. (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.) Fig. 8 Table 1 Characteristics of impregnated FCC catalysts. Souza a I. Tkach b E. Morgado Jr. c K. Krambrock a ⁎ a UFMG, Physics Department, Belo Horizonte, Brazil UFMG Physics Department Belo Horizonte Brazil b Max Planck Institute, Göttingen, Germany Max Planck Institute Göttingen Germany c Petrobras S.A., CENPES, Rio de Janeiro, RJ, Brazil Petrobras S.A. CENPES Rio de Janeiro RJ Brazil ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Amongst the contaminant transition metals Fe, Ni, V that deposits onto the fluid catalytic cracking (FCC) catalyst and promote unwanted secondary reactions, vanadium is the most deleterious one because not only acts as undesired dehydrogenation site but also migrates deeper inside the catalyst particles under the FCC regeneration conditions, stabilizing in different phases that attack the crystalline structure of the catalyst, thus resulting in its irreversible loss of activity. The mechanisms through which vanadium affect the catalyst during its use in the FCC process remain under debate and the accurate determination of the chemical species involved and of their concentration is of paramount importance for the investigations in this field. In this work, a quantification methodology for contaminant vanadium in FCC catalysts was developed based on X-ray fluorescence (XRF) and electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR). A commercial FCC catalyst was artificially contaminated with vanadium at different loads by pore volume impregnation with aqueous vanadyl sulfate solution, in the presence or not of a complexing agent, followed by steam deactivation at 788 °C/5 h, and the samples were compared to spent FCC catalysts from different Brazilian refineries. It has been shown that EPR is a very sensitive and reliable technique to quantify vanadyl ions (V4+) in FCC catalysts while lower valence states such as V3+ have not been detected in any of the samples studied. Vanadyl ions (VO2+) deposited onto the catalyst are mostly oxidized to higher valence state species and the extent of this oxidation in equilibrium catalysts from FCC units was calculated and related to the combustion mode at which the FCC regenerators operate. The artificial vanadium contamination and deactivation protocol adopted in this work resulted in a proportion of V4+/Vtotal of nearly 10%, similar to that of equilibrium catalysts sampled from FCC units with full combustion regeneration. The present study brings a new interpretation for the EPR signal detected as a broad unstructured line, with evidences of some vanadium existing as a ferri-/ferromagnetic surface phase in the catalyst particles, likely formed by induced oxygen vacancies during reaction (reducing atmosphere) and quite resistant to the regeneration step. Keywords FCC catalyst Metal contamination Vanadium XRF EPR 1 Introduction Fluid catalytic cracking (FCC) is a key process in oil refineries that converts low-valued heavy oil fractions into products of greater added value for the market, such as gasoline and propylene [1]. The FCC process starts with the injection of pre-heated gasoil to the base of a riser reactor, where it is vaporized and brought into contact for few seconds with hot FCC catalyst particles. Thereafter, the spent solid catalyst, which is deactivated by coke, is separated from the formed products and goes to the regenerator, where the catalyst particles are recovered by burning the coke in air flow at high temperatures. One strategy to improve refinery margins is to process heavier crude oils and consequently more contaminated feedstock is fed to the FCC process [2], leading to higher deposition of transition metals, such as iron (Fe), nickel (Ni) and vanadium (V), on the circulating FCC catalyst, which causes its continuous and irreversible damage. In order to maintain a minimum level of activity and selectivity to the catalyst inventory, the equilibrium catalyst (Ecat) is continuously purged from the unit and exchanged with fresh catalyst [3]. FCC catalysts are basically porous microspheres containing crystalline Y zeolite dispersed in a silica-alumina-clay matrix. While the zeolite provides most of the cracking activity, the matrix fulfills both physical and catalytic functions. The detrimental effects of the metal contaminants over the catalyst performance during FCC operation is well known. Nickel, iron and vanadium promote dehydrogenation reactions, which increases undesirable products like coke and hydrogen, but vanadium also destroys the crystalline zeolite framework in the presence of steam generated in the FCC regenerator, thus causing loss of catalytic activity [4,5]. Besides, vanadium is the one with the greatest mobility, accumulating throughout catalyst particles [5–7] or at least penetrating deeper into the particles than other contaminant metals [8]. Meta-vanadic acid (H3VO4) is claimed to be the species resulting from the hydrolysis of deposited vanadium pentoxide (V2O5) and water vapor under high-temperature oxidizing conditions and being capable of permeating the innermost layers of the catalyst particles [9,10]. It may react with cationic sodium facilitating its release from the Y zeolite exchange sites [11], thus sustaining the collapse of the remaining zeolitic structure via hydrolysis of the framework aluminum. Despite the well-known deleterious and mobile effect of vanadium over FCC catalysts, few studies have been dedicated to investigate the phase transformations and different valence states of vanadium in this context. By using electron paramagnetic resonance and micro-activity testing of non-reduced and reduced samples of FCC catalysts, Tangstad et al. [12] concluded that V4+ and V5+ have quite similar dehydrogenation activities while V3+ or lower oxidation states have aproximately no dehydrogenation effect. However, only higher oxidation states of vanadium (V4+/V5+) have been found in equilbrium catalysts of commercial operations [13]. In order to study the mechanism of metals contamination in FCC catalysts, virgin samples are impregnated in laboratory by different methods. Due to its simplicity and robustness, the metals deposition by the insipient wetness (pore volume) technique with Ni and V compounds followed by calcination and steam deactivation, proposed by Mitchell in 1980 [14], is the most widely used method. However, it is well known that these artificial metalation methods do no match the deposition of the metals on the outer surface and can lead to exaggerated and unrealistic dehydrogenation activity [15]. Ni and V naphthenates dissolved in organic solvents are often preferred precursors due to their similarity to the metal porphyrins found in the crude oil. However, water-soluble precursors can be successfully used [16] with the advantage of being safer to handle and ecologically correct. In the present work, vanadyl sulfate was used as aqueous impregnating precursor to prepare vanadium impregnated FCC samples and part of them was exploratory made in the presence of EDTA, a hexadentate ligand molecule, intuitively proposed to replace the role of the conventional organometallic precursors. By examining the electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectra of these artificially impregnated samples and also of contaminated catalysts from industrial FCC units, the present work is focused on the speciation and proper quantification of vanadium on such samples. In a previous study applying the EPR technique in a FCC equilibrium catalyst, calibration mixtures of known amounts of impregnated paramagnetic Ni0 and V4+ ions were used to quantify nickel and vanadium contaminants by double integration of the EPR signal [13]. However, the quantification method was not clearly stated and differs in certain points of that proposed in this work. In this paper a quantification methodology is disclosed based on the total vanadium content measured by X-ray fluorescence (XRF) and a detailed EPR study to determine the proportion of paramagnetic charge states of vanadium, such as V4+ and V3+, in artificially metalized deactivated FCC catalysts, which are compared to real equilibrium catalysts collected from FCC units of Brazilian refineries. 2 Materiais and methods 2.1 Instrumentation Total vanadium content in the catalysts was determined by X-ray fluorescence spectroscopy according to standard quantitative method (ASTM D7085) after proper instrument calibration and applied on test specimens prepared by the fused bead technique. EPR measurements at room temperature were done on a commercial X-band EPR spectrometer, model Miniscope MS400 (Magnettech – Germany). For low temperature measurements, a home-built EPR spectrometer was used including commercial X-band resonator (Bruker), Varian magnet, Varian klystron microwave source, and He flux cryosystem model ESR 910 (Oxford). Typical parameters were: center field 350 mT, sweep range 500 mT, modulation amplitude 0.2–0.5 mT, microwave power of 0.1–10 mW. Due to the magnetic field modulation (100 kHz), the EPR spectra were measured as first derivates. For the EPR measurements, a certain quantity of FCC catalyst, in general 50.0 mg, were weighed on analytical balance model AWM2020 (Shimadzu) with precision of 0.1 mg inside quartz tubes (Wilmad Labglass). The EPR technique is a very sensitive and quantitative technique for determination of paramagnetic species. In general, for the quantification process a well-known calibration standard is measured and by double integration the area below the absorption curve determined, which is proportional to the absolute spin concentration. 2.2 Reagents, materials and samples For quantitative determination of vanadium (V4+) in FCC catalysts, the EPR equipment was calibrated by using different amounts of anhydrous vanadyl sulfate (VOSO4) and the spectral parameters optimized such as modulation amplitude, sweep range, gain, microwave power and sample mass. A commercial fresh FCC catalyst was pre-calcined at 600 °C for 1 h and impregnated with aqueous solutions of VOSO4 by insipient wetness method at different conditions (see Table 1 ) involving different contents of vanadium (typical of equilibrium FCC catalysts) and the use or not of EDTA as complexing agent. In this latter case, an EDTA aqueous solution with pH adjusted to 5.5 with NH4OH (to keep product dissolved) was previously prepared and mixed to the VOSO4 solution (C1–C4). For the sake of comparison, all four reference impregnations without EDTA had also their VOSO4 solutions adjusted to pH 5.5 (C5–C8). After impregnation, all samples were dried overnight at 110 °C and the resulting powder submitted to 100% steam flow at 788 °C for 5 h, trying to simulate the hydrothermal deactivation that occurs in real FCC units. Samples before and after steam deactivation were analyzed by EPR. Nominal and measured total vanadium content are shown in Table 1 as well. For the C-4 sample, thermal treatments were performed in different atmospheres and at different temperatures in order to better understand the transformation of vanadium in the impregnated FCC catalysts. For this purpose, thermal treatments were carried out in a tubular furnace under oxidizing or reducing atmospheres, using dry air or gas mixture consisting of 10% H2 : 90% N2, respectively, for one hour at 150 °C, 300 °C, 505 °C and 750 °C. For comparison with industrial operation, other set of eight contaminated equilibrium FCC catalysts (ECAT) collected from different refineries, some operating their FCC regenerators in partial burn (∼0.2% C left) and others in full combustion (<0.05% C left) were analyzed. V concentrations of these real catalysts as determined by XRF analysis are shown in Table 2 . These samples, particularly the ones from partial burn units, were submitted to further regeneration in pilot riser unit operating its regeneration step at 720 °C with excess of oxygen to remove all remained carbon and were analyzed again by EPR. 2.3 Calibration and analytical aspects Pure anhydrous samples of vanadyl sulfate (VOSO4) with different mass ranging from 0.9 to 10.2 mg were used as vanadium standard for calibration of EPR spectra and measured at room temperature. Optimized spectral parameters were: center field 350 mT, microwave power of 10 mW, modulation amplitude 0.2 mT, sweep range 500 mT and variable gain. The gain of the spectrometer has been checked and found that it varies linearly with the concentration. After measurements, EPR spectra were adjusted by theoretical spectra using Easyspin@ software and double integrated to get the area below the absorption curve, thus allowing the calculation of the vanadium concentration determined in ppm. The method to obtain theoretical EPR spectra for vanadyl ions is given in the Supplementary info. It has been found that this procedure gives more reliable results than the direct double integration of the experimental spectra due to baseline contributions. The C-4 catalyst impregnated with nominal 1500 ppm V using vanadyl sulfate and EDTA was used to verify the response of the EPR spectrometer as a function of the catalyst mass (10 mg–150 mg), since the ordinary analysis of the impregnated and equilibrium catalysts were made with samples mass of 50 mg. From the double integration of these spectra, the respective areas were determined and related to the concentrations in part per million (ppm) of vanadium in the samples. Under the same experimental conditions, all the impregnated and real catalysts were analyzed using 50 mg mass of catalysts. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Spectral features The basic technique for our quantification study in this work is based on electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR). A typical EPR spectrum measured at room temperature of a real equilibrium catalyst sample is shown in Fig. 1 . The EPR spectrum shown in Fig. 1 consists of three signals due to different paramagnetic species. In the ECAT-5 sample it is possible to identify a signal assigned to Fe3+ (S = 5/2) around 150 mT, which comes from kaolin as a catalyst component (not contaminant iron) and a signal with a hyperfine structure centered around 335 mT, characteristic of the vanadyl ions (VO2+) and very similar to the EPR spectrum of vanadyl ions in crude petroleum. The third is a broad and unidentified EPR signal. According to literature, this broad EPR signal of unproven origin might be due to Ni0 species [13], due to ferri-/ferromagnetic species involving iron [17] or even due to amorphous V2O4 clusters [10,18]. The attribution of the low-field EPR line (∼150 mT) to structural Fe3+ in the meta-kaolinite structure is based on experiments done on fresh non-impregnated and ferric iron impregnated FCC catalysts which will be presented in forthcoming publication [17]. Fig. 2 shows the experimental and calculated spectra for the vanadium impregnated catalyst C4 in comparison to the real catalyst ECAT-3 sample containing vanadyl species. It can be easily observed that spectral parameters of vanadyl ions are different when comparing both types of samples. The individual line widths of vanadyl ions in the real catalyst are much broader (about a factor of 2) when compared with that of impregnated catalyst. In addition, the real catalyst shows two different vanadyl sites (marked by arrows). A quantification based on the intensity of the second or third more intense EPR line of vanadyl, as often used in literature [10,13], would give mistaken vanadyl concentrations. Therefore, the only way to get good quantification results is the use of the double integration of the theoretical spectra that have been adjusted to the experimental ones after background subtraction. The spin Hamiltonian parameters of vanadyl ions in the calculated spectra of Fig. 2 are given in Table 3 and compared to those reported in literature for vanadium interacting with Y-zeolites [19,20]. The EPR spectra are described by axial g and A tensors, very similar to those in the spectra measured in crude oil [21]. The powder spectrum is a superposition of one parallel and two axial components of octets caused by the hyperfine interaction. The individual line shape of the spectra is Gaussian, indicating unresolved hyperfine interactions as for example with Al neighbors of the catalyst particle (I = 5/2, 100% natural abundance). From the values presented in Table 3, one can notice that for the impregnated catalyst only one type of site is occupied by the vanadyl ions, while for the real catalyst two sites are clearly resolved, similarly to the work presented by Huang et al. [19] on solid-state ion exchanged zeolite. Both the g tensor and hyperfine tensors A of vanadyl ions in the FCC catalysts studied in this work are slightly different from the ones in pure Y zeolites, indicating some change in the local arrangements when the zeolite is incorporated in the FCC catalyst. 3.2 Calibration of the vanadyl ion (VO2+) The EPR spectra of anhydrous vanadyl sulfate as a function of mass (1–10 mg) are shown in Fig. 3 a. The EPR spectra do not show the 8-line hyperfine-split spectrum as observed for the impregnated and real FCC catalyst samples due to exchange interaction between nearby vanadium ions. Subsequently, calculations of the areas for each EPR spectrum were made by double integration of the absorptions. The EPR spectra for the impregnated sample C-4, also as a function of mass (10–150 mg), are shown in Fig. 3b and are very similar to the EPR spectra of isolated vanadyl ions reported in the literature [10,18,19]. For the impregnated C-4 catalyst (50.0 mg sample mass), the theoretical spectrum closest to the experimental spectrum was calculated, as explained before and double integrated to obtain the area, avoiding errors due to integration in the presence of baseline. The area was compared to the area obtained for pure vanadyl sulfate, which was corrected based on the linear relationship between mass and area, since it was not possible to measure the spectrum of a 50 mg sample for pure vanadyl sulfate. The graph in Fig. 4 a shows the dependence of the area of the double-integrated EPR line of vanadyl sulfate as a function of the mass ranging from 0 to 10 mg. The EPR spectrometer response (gain) is quite linear, with an error of only 2.2%, for samples with masses between 0 and 10 mg, which is the maximum amount of pure VOSO4 that the equipment can couple and generate the spectrum. However, for the impregnated and real catalyst samples we worked with a larger sample mass in order to increase sensitivity, equivalent to 50 mg, to generate the EPR spectra. For this purpose, the C-4 catalyst sample impregnated with about 1500 ppm of vanadium was used and the spectra were measured for samples from 10 mg to 150 mg, as shown in Fig. 3b. The area determined by double integration of these EPR spectra are given in the graph of Fig. 4b. Note that for larger masses (above 10 mg) the spectrometer response is not linear, but described by a Boltzmann type sigmoid saturation curve. Therefore, for calculations of concentrations, we have to take into account a correction factor according to Fig. 4b. 3.3 Quantification of vanadium in the series of impregnated catalysts C-1 to C-8 The EPR spectra for the impregnated catalysts C-1 to C-8 series (Table 1) are displayed in Fig. 5 and Table 4 lists the vanadyl concentration in ppm for all impregnated catalyst samples before and after steam deactivation. The EPR spectra of the impregnated samples C1I-C4I and deactivated samples C1D-C4D are shown in Fig. 5a and b, respectively, where complexing agent EDTA was used during impregnation. Fig. 5c and d show the spectra for the same samples without use of EDTA (samples C5I-C8I and C5D-C8D). Comparing Fig. 5a and c we note stronger intensities of the EPR spectra when using EDTA with the charge state of vanadyl ions much better maintained. However, after steam deactivation at 788 °C, all samples either with or without complexing agent EDTA lead to nearly the same and significantly reduced vanadyl concentrations. As presented in Table 4, there is a noticeable difference between the concentration in parts per million of the total vanadium on the impregnated catalysts (Table 1, XRF data) and of the vanadium (IV) calculated by means of EPR, so that V4+/Vtotal ratio varied between 29 and 39% in the catalysts impregnated in the presence of EDTA and between 14 and 21% in the reference impregnated catalysts. It indicates that vanadium (IV) undergoes partial oxidation during the impregnation step and its signal is no longer captured by EPR since undetectable species such as V2O5 are likely formed [10,18,19,21]. Besides, it became quantitatively demonstrated that the complexing agent is able to retard the V4+ consumption process until the impregnated sample is dried. However, after steam deactivation, when EDTA is completely decomposed (confirmed by measuring 0% carbon remained), most of the vanadyl is converted and all samples resulted within the range of 8–11% of V4+ from the total vanadium. Another path that emerged as a possibility was the reduction of V4+ into V3+ [12] due to the ion exchange with other element present in the catalyst sample. Vanadium III (spin S = 1) is paramagnetic, but due to a strong fine structure interaction this EPR signal cannot be easily observed at X-band frequencies [22]. For that reason, high frequency EPR measurements have been done at 261 GHz and low temperature (20 K). However, the EPR measurements at high frequency gave similar spectra as those observed at X-band (10 GHz). The high frequency EPR measurements of samples C-4I and C-4D are included as supplementary material (Fig. S1). From that we conclude that lower valence states of vanadium can be excluded and the steam deactivation process leads only to oxidation of vanadium to V5+, probably in the form of vanadium pentoxide (V2O5) or even as vanadate (VO4 3−) [9–11]. Heat treatments on impregnated FCC catalysts under different atmospheres give important information about phase transformations and bonding sites of vanadium. Fig. 6 shows the EPR spectra obtained on a vanadium impregnated sample (1500 ppm) that was thermally treated at different temperatures for 1 h under (a) oxidizing (air) and (b) reducing (H2:N2, 10:90) atmospheres. Different conclusions can be drawn from the EPR spectra shown in Fig. 6. The total concentration of vanadyl ions as measured by EPR when thermally treated in oxidizing or reducing atmospheres are not strongly modified until 500 °C. For the highest temperatures, the EPR line intensities of vanadyl ions decrease a little, but spectra clearly broaden especially after reduction treatment, indicating local re-arrangement of vanadyl ions in different sites. The double integration of spectra shows that the concentration is nearly maintained. On the other hand, Fe3+ EPR signals (∼150 mT) from the kaolin matrix increase as a function of temperature when treated in oxidizing atmosphere until 750 °C, gaining about a factor of 2 in intensity, indicating that some Fe2+ ions substituting for Al sites in the clay matrix are oxidized to Fe3+. Reversibly, when the samples are treated in reducing atmosphere the Fe3+ EPR lines of the clay are reduced continuously by a factor of about 2 at 750 °C, indicating reduction of Fe3+ to Fe2+. It is noticed a considerable modification in EPR spectra for heat treatments under reducing atmosphere at temperatures above 500 °C (Fig. 6b). A broad line appears in the EPR spectra. Tests were done with virgin catalyst to compare it with the corresponding vanadium impregnated catalyst and to discover the possible origin that generates this line. The virgin catalyst was subjected to thermal treatments at different temperatures and times under a reducing atmosphere of gas mixture containing 10% H2 and 90% N2. The spectra are shown in Fig. 7 . The EPR spectra obtained for the vanadium impregnated catalysts (Fig. 6b) and the virgin catalysts (Fig. 7) were then compared. Around 500 °C the broad EPR line appears with high intensity for both catalysts under reducing atmosphere, but for thermal treatments at higher temperatures or prolonged times the broad EPR line of the virgin catalysts tends to diminish and becomes more anisotropic, while the broad EPR line for the impregnated catalyst remains constant. We associate the origin of the broad EPR line in the virgin catalyst to surface defect states induced by the reduction treatment. However, these surface defects are not isolated defects, i.e. the broad line is not of paramagnetic origin, but representing a magnetic phase. This magnetic phase is a ferri-/ferromagnetic phase likely formed by interacting oxygen vacancies at the surface. Such surface defects are probably created due to the prolonged treatments under these reducing conditions. When metal impurities like vanadium are present this ferri-/ferromagnetic phase is stabilized at the surface, which is clearly seen in Fig. 6b. The stabilized surface phase of vanadium for the V-impregnated samples cannot be due to paramagnetic species but ferri-/ferromagnetic species, because double integration of the EPR spectra shows that the concentration of vanadium would be well above the total vanadium content as measured by XRF. As the vanadyl EPR spectra are not strongly affected by these thermal treatments, it means that other diamagnetic vanadium species related with the surface are transformed. In literature, these species are frequently attributed to V2O4 clusters formed from diamagnetic V2O5 species [10,18]. This process is discussed below. Compared to metal contaminants of the FCC catalysts like Ni and Fe, vanadium is quite mobile and penetrates much deeper into the catalyst particles [6–8]. Vanadium may establish VOAl and VOSi bonds within the aluminum silicate structures of the FCC catalyst. According to Trujillo [12], when vanadium is in the form of vanadyl ions (VO2+), it tends to be stabilized at the acidic sites. These sites can be either of the Lewis-type, being able to exchange electrons, or of the Brönsted-Lowry-type, in which there is exchange of a proton, H+. These conclusions are in agreement to our observations. Possible reaction models would be: (1) Coordinated tetrahedral and octahedral Al ions are found in FCC catalysts. The first in the crystalline zeolite structure and the second in the amorphous alumina part, such as extra-framework Al. Once vanadyl ions are stabilized at the acidic sites, simple oxidative and reductive thermal treatments do only slightly affect these ions. On the other hand, when vanadium is present in the form of dimers V2O4 it tends to polymerize, forming clusters, and in addition, has strong tendency to oxidize, according to Eq. (2) [10]: (2) 2 V2O4 + O2 ↔ 2 V2O5 Eq. (2) can also be inverted under reducing atmospheres to produce V2O4 clusters, which are responsible for the broad EPR line observed when samples are treated above 500 °C. The measurements carried out in the present work suggest a new perspective on the compound that generates the broad EPR line after reduction at high temperature. According to previous work [10] this broad line is formed by polymerization of V2O4 dimers. However, our results revealed that the broad EPR line is also produced when the fresh catalyst with no vanadium present is reduced. Therefore, we suggest that the reduction treatment induces many oxygen vacancies, which are stabilized by vanadium to form the ferri-/ferromagnetic phase observed as a broad line by EPR spectroscopy. From the present study it is difficult to conclude which part of the FCC catalyst particle is more susceptible to the formation of oxygen vacancies under cracking conditions. 3.4 Quantification of vanadium in real catalysts In general, the EPR spectra of the real FCC catalysts used in refineries are similar to those of vanadium impregnated FCC catalysts. However, the former always show intense broad EPR lines whose origin, as discussed before, is probably due to ferri-/or ferromagnetic nanoclusters of transition metal ions. Such EPR signal may be not only due to vanadium, but also due to nickel or iron, which is subject of a separate publication [17]. The EPR spectra measured at room temperature of the ECAT-3 and ECAT-5 samples before and after further regeneration step are shown in Fig. 8 a and b. ECAT-3 sample originate from a FCC unit that works with complete combustion and ECAT-5 sample from a unit operating at partial combustion. The EPR spectra of the equilibrium catalysts ECAT-3 and ECAT-5 present a dominant broad EPR line superimposed by the vanadyl ion spectrum and the Fe3+ line from the kaolin matrix. After further oxidative regeneration step, the Fe3+ EPR line and the broad line increase for both samples, much stronger for FCC catalyst from partial combustion, and the EPR spectra of vanadyl ions decrease. As described before, in order to determine the vanadyl concentrations in the real catalysts, the EPR spectra were cut in the region of the magnetic field between 250 mT and 450 mT and a broad baseline correction applied. After a theoretical spectrum was calculated (see Supplementary info) and adjusted to the experimental one, a double integration was applied to determine the area, from which the calibration curve with anhydrous vanadyl sulfate permitted to determine the vanadyl concentration in ppm. Table 5 shows the obtained concentrations of V4+ (EPR) and of total vanadium (XRF) in ppm. As expected, the four equilibrium catalysts that experienced partial burn regeneration exhibited the highest proportion of V4+up to 33%, whereas those from full combustion FCC units resulted in only 5–16%, more in line with the percentages found for the artificially deactivated catalysts (Table 4). The ECAT-3 sample is approximately 3 times more contaminated in vanadium than ECAT-5. Nevertheless, the vanadyl ion content is higher in the ECAT-5 sample, which circulated in a FCC unit with less oxidizing regeneration environment (partial combustion) than ECAT-3sample from a full combustion unit. The further reduction in vanadyl concentration for all samples after further oxidative regeneration in pilot FCC unit demonstrates the consistency of the quantitative EPR measurements. The broad EPR lines of the as-such equilibrium catalysts ECAT-3 and ECAT-5 have nearly the same intensity, but its increase after further regeneration step was much stronger for ECAT-5 (Fig. 8). Lower valance states of vanadium, such as V3+ was not detected in the equilibrium catalysts. Petroleum contains vanadium in the form of vanadyl ions, mostly within porphyrin molecules. These tend to be concentrated in the heavier fraction after distillation that is used as feed for the FCC process, and decompose by catalytic cracking, probably still preserving most of the vanadyl ions within the coke deposited on the catalyst surface. However, our quantitative measurements with the equilibrium catalysts proves that after regeneration, most of the present vanadium is already oxidized, even in those cases where the catalyst experiences milder regeneration conditions (partial burn). One of the difficulties of quantifying vanadyl ions by EPR spectra measured at room temperature in the real FCC catalysts is related to the presence of broad EPR lines, which have to be subtracted before the double integration of spectra. EPR measurements at low temperatures (<20 K) (see Fig. S2 Supplementary info) facilitate the quantification process. At these temperatures, the broad EPR lines disappear almost completely, leaving only spectra of Fe3+ from kaolin matrix and VO2+ that can be easily double integrated. For the impregnated FCC catalysts studied in this work the broad EPR lines are related with vanadium, however, for real catalysts not only vanadium may be responsible for this line, but also nickel and iron have to be considered. When working with EPR measurements at low temperatures there is a high gain in sensitivity, increasing signal intensity due to increase in the occupation difference (Boltzmann factor) between the spin levels, generating less noisy spectra, which improves the quantification of vanadium. On the other hand, EPR measurements at low temperatures take more time and the cost-benefit is not as high to justify its use. Therefore, the use of EPR technique at room temperature was chosen to perform the measurements in this work. All impregnated and real equilibrium FCC catalyst samples investigated in this study were also analyzed by EPR at low temperature (10 K). Within an error of 3% the quantification results for V4+ are the same as that of the room temperature measurements. 4 Conclusions It has been shown that EPR is a very sensitive (∼1 ppm) and reliable technique (errors within 10%) to quantify vanadyl ions (V4+) in FCC catalyst particles and together with X-ray fluorescence can elucidate important aspects of the vanadium contamination in FCC catalysts. Lower valence states of vanadium such as V3+ have not been detected by EPR in none of the samples studied, even at high microwave frequencies and may not exist. From the present quantification study of vanadium poisoning in FCC catalysts we conclude that most part of the deposited vanadyl ions (VO2+) from feedstock is oxidized after artificial hydrothermal deactivation in laboratory or regeneration in commercial FCC units. The quantitative method was also able to distinguish the extent of this oxidation in equilibrium catalysts from FCC units operating at partial or full combustion mode with up to 33% of remaining V4+ found in the former case and no more than 16% in the second case. Besides, further drop in concentration of this reduced species to lower than 10% was verified when equilibrium catalysts were submitted to further oxidizing regeneration in pilot FCC unit. The artificial deactivation protocol by insipient wetness impregnation of fresh FCC catalyst with aqueous solution of vanadyl sulfate followed by accelerated steam deactivation (100% steam at 788 °C/5 h) resulted in a proportion of V4+/Vtotal of nearly 10%, similar to that of equilibrium catalysts sampled from FCC units with full combustion regeneration. The tentative use of a complexing agent (EDTA) during the impregnation step succeeded in retarding the oxidation of the vanadyl ions; however, after steaming of the dried powder to simulate the hydrothermal deactivation in real FCC units, the amount of V4+ leveled off with that of samples impregnated without EDTA. Apart from vanadium trapped at the acidic sites of the FCC catalysts, other part is stabilized in a ferri-/ferromagnetic surface phase of the catalyst particles, which is detected by EPR as a broad unstructured line. This phase is likely formed by induced oxygen vacancies at the surface under hydrocarbon cracking conditions (∼500 °C, reducing atmosphere) and is quite resistant to the regeneration step, where the FCC catalyst particles undergo higher temperatures (∼750 °C) under oxidative atmospheres. Further quantitative studies of V4+/V5+ species in FCC catalysts based on the presented methodology using XRF and EPR are highly desirable to evaluate and compare different metal deactivation protocols and also different catalyst formulations. Acknowledgements Thanks are due to Marco Antonio S. de Abreu for the preparation of the vanadium impregnated samples. Two of the authors, N.L.A. Souza and K. Krambrock, are grateful to PETROBRAS S.A. for financial support (ANP project number 2014/00531-9). Appendix A Supplementary data Supplementary material related to this article can be found, in the online version, at doi:https://doi.org/10.1016/j.apcata.2018.05.003. coredata.dc:description: Amongst the contaminant transition metals Fe, Ni, V that deposits onto the fluid catalytic cracking (FCC) catalyst and promote unwanted secondary reactions, vanadium is the most deleterious one because not only acts as undesired dehydrogenation site but also migrates deeper inside the catalyst particles under the FCC regeneration conditions, stabilizing in different phases that attack the crystalline structure of the catalyst, thus resulting in its irreversible loss of activity. The mechanisms through which vanadium affect the catalyst during its use in the FCC process remain under debate and the accurate determination of the chemical species involved and of their concentration is of paramount importance for the investigations in this field. In this work, a quantification methodology for contaminant vanadium in FCC catalysts was developed based on X-ray fluorescence (XRF) and electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR). A commercial FCC catalyst was artificially contaminated with vanadium at different loads by pore volume impregnation with aqueous vanadyl sulfate solution, in the presence or not of a complexing agent, followed by steam deactivation at 788 °C/5 h, and the samples were compared to spent FCC catalysts from different Brazilian refineries. It has been shown that EPR is a very sensitive and reliable technique to quantify vanadyl ions (V4+) in FCC catalysts while lower valence states such as V3+ have not been detected in any of the samples studied. Vanadyl ions (VO2+) deposited onto the catalyst are mostly oxidized to higher valence state species and the extent of this oxidation in equilibrium catalysts from FCC units was calculated and related to the combustion mode at which the FCC regenerators operate. The artificial vanadium contamination and deactivation protocol adopted in this work resulted in a proportion of V4+/Vtotal of nearly 10%, similar to that of equilibrium catalysts sampled from FCC units with full combustion regeneration. The present study brings a new interpretation for the EPR signal detected as a broad unstructured line, with evidences of some vanadium existing as a ferri-/ferromagnetic surface phase in the catalyst particles, likely formed by induced oxygen vacancies during reaction (reducing atmosphere) and quite resistant to the regeneration step.
coredata.dc:title: Vanadium poisoning of FCC catalysts: A quantitative analysis of impregnated and real equilibrium catalysts
